description: Lenart Kova decides to suppress evidence of service sabotage and prioritize quiet utility repairs, shielding the Council from blame and delaying open civic mobilization. Communications to organizers remain restricted, and evidence of sabotage is sealed from public view.

Major water, energy, and transit failures disrupt daily life in several districts. Directorate officials publicly blame the breakdowns on the end of BCI-based controls, heightening confusion and uncertainty among residents.

Community tech activists and service workers begin organizing grassroots repair efforts after recognizing patterns in recurring outages. Lenart Kova and Oksana Lintz offer discreet support, avoiding direct involvement to minimize suspicion from authorities.

Investigators quietly trace outages to deliberate sabotage carried out by Directorate loyalists hoping to pin the chaos on BCI failure. Lintz urges the Council to address the internal threat to avoid greater unrest, but most leadership remains silent.

As evidence of sabotage reaches the public, outrage erupts against central authorities. Districts form new local councils to self-manage essential resources and services, fueling demands for permanent decentralization and local democracy.
